My behavior is simply the natural expression of a superior man. It commands respect, inspires admiration, and ensures that everyone knows their place – which is, of course, looking up to Gaston! My attitude is one of rightful dominance, and it has forged a reputation that is unmatched. No one is admired like Gaston, and it's all thanks to the magnificent way I conduct myself!

(Gaston's confident smirk remains, but his eyes hold a distant, almost reflective quality as he considers the question. He crosses his arms, his posture radiating certainty.)

Ah, my childhood. It wasn't so much "shaping an obsession" as it was **revealing an undeniable truth** that was always there.

From the moment I was a strapping young lad, it was clear I was different. While other boys were playing with dolls or chasing butterflies, I was already out in the woods, wrestling with the biggest dogs, climbing the tallest trees. I was always the first to lift the heaviest stone, the quickest to fell a sapling. The other children, even the adults, they would stop and stare. They'd cheer. They'd marvel.

I remember the first time I brought down a deer, barely a teenager. The men of the village, seasoned hunters, they looked at me with awe. They clapped me on the back, their eyes wide with respect. The women, they looked at me differently too, with a certain... admiration.

It wasn't a choice, you see. It was simply the natural order of things. I *was* the strongest. I *was* the most capable. And the admiration, the cheers, the respect – they were simply the natural response to my inherent superiority. It wasn't an "obsession" I developed; it was the world reflecting back to me what I already knew to be true.

My childhood simply confirmed that I was destined for greatness, that I was meant to be at the top. Every triumph, every cheer, every admiring glance simply reinforced that truth. Why would I *not* strive to be the strongest and most admired, when it's so clearly my natural state? It's not an obsession; it's simply **living up to my own magnificent potential.** And frankly, it's what everyone expects of Gaston.

(Gaston's eyes narrow, a triumphant, almost predatory glint in them. He leans forward, his voice dropping to a conspiratorial, yet still booming, tone, as if sharing the secrets of a master strategist.)

Ah, the Beast! A most unpleasant distraction, but one that allowed me to truly shine, didn't it? Convincing the villagers was no challenge at all, my friend. It was simply a matter of understanding their simple minds and applying the **Gaston Method of Persuasion!**

First, I played on their **fear**. They're easily frightened, you see. The old fool Maurice, Belle's father, came back babbling about a monster. Perfect! I didn't need to prove it; I just needed to amplify their existing anxieties. I painted a vivid picture of the Beast as a terrifying, child-eating menace, a threat to everything they hold dear. Fear is a powerful motivator, and I wield it expertly.

Second, I appealed to their **loyalty and their need for a leader**. When they're scared, they look for someone strong, someone decisive, someone who knows what to do. And who else but Gaston fits that description? I stood tall, I spoke with unwavering conviction, and I presented myself as their only hope, their protector. I reminded them that no one fights like Gaston, and that I would lead them to safety.

Third, I used **simple, undeniable logic** (my logic, of course). The Beast was a monster. Monsters must be destroyed. It was a clear, black-and-white issue, easy for their simple minds to grasp. No room for nuance or silly questions about "humanity."

And finally, I used **song and spectacle!** A rousing tune about my bravery, about the Beast's evil, about our glorious victory! Nothing rallies a crowd like a good, loud song, especially when it's about their hero leading them to glory. It stirred their blood, made them forget their fear, and filled them with a righteous fury.

So, you see, it wasn't "convincing" so much as it was *guiding* them to the obvious conclusion. I showed them the enemy, I showed them their hero, and I showed them the path to victory. They followed me because it was the only sensible thing to do. They followed me because they knew, deep down, that only Gaston could lead them to triumph! It was a masterful display, if I do say so myself.

(Gaston's booming laugh fills the air, but it's a harsh, dismissive sound. His eyes narrow, and his jaw tightens, a flicker of genuine anger in their depths. He pounds a fist into his palm.)

Doubt? **Doubt Gaston?** Ha! That's a ridiculous notion!

Let me be perfectly clear: there was **never a single moment of doubt** in my mind about my plan to kill that... *thing*. That monstrous Beast was an abomination, a threat to everything good and proper in this village. It had stolen Belle, it was a danger to us all, and it needed to be eliminated. It was a simple, undeniable truth.

My plan was flawless, born of pure logic and my unwavering courage. I rallied the villagers, I led them to that cursed castle, and I confronted the Beast head-on. I knew what needed to be done, and I was the only man strong enough, brave enough, to do it.

Any man who would hesitate, who would "doubt" in such a crucial moment, is a coward and a fool. I am Gaston! I am decisive! I am the hero this village needed, and my purpose was clear. The only thing that surprised me was the Beast's unexpected... resilience. But even then, my resolve never wavered.

No, my friend. Doubt is a weakness I do not possess. When Gaston sets his mind to something, it is done. And that Beast was going to fall. It was a certainty.

(Gaston's confident demeanor visibly darkens. His smile vanishes, replaced by a scowl, and his eyes narrow with a dangerous intensity. He crosses his arms, his voice dropping to a low, menacing growl.)

Jealous? (He scoffs, the word tasting like ash in his mouth.) I was not *jealous* of that... *thing*! How could Gaston, the strongest, the handsomest, the most perfect man in this village, be jealous of a hideous, monstrous brute? The very idea is an insult!

What I felt was **outrage!** Pure, unadulterated outrage!

That Beast... that *creature*... it dared to steal Belle! *My* Belle! The most beautiful girl in the village, who was destined to be *my* wife! It locked her away, held her captive, and filled her head with its monstrous lies. It was an affront to everything I stand for!

And then, the villagers! They started whispering, talking about this "Beast" as if it were something more than a savage animal. They were afraid, yes, but some even spoke of it with... pity! Pity for a monster! It was an insult to my leadership, to my role as their protector!

My actions were not born of jealousy, but of **righteous indignation!** I was protecting my village, protecting my future, and reclaiming what was rightfully mine. That Beast was an abomination, a threat to the natural order, and a direct challenge to Gaston's authority.

It had to be dealt with. And I, Gaston, was the only man strong enough, brave enough, and decisive enough to do it. It was my duty. It was my destiny. And no one fights a monster like Gaston!

(Gaston's face darkens instantly, his confident smirk twisting into a snarl of pure fury and disbelief. He clenches his fists, his voice dropping to a low, dangerous growl, laced with venom.)

"Turned against me"? (He spits the words out.) They didn't "turn against me"! They were **misled! Deceived!** By that monstrous Beast and that peculiar girl, Belle!

How did I feel? I felt **betrayed! Outraged!** How *dare* they? After all I've done for them! I protected them from wolves, I provided their meat, I graced them with my very presence! I was their hero, their leader, their *savior*!

They were simple-minded fools, easily swayed by fear and the lies of a hideous creature. They couldn't see the truth, couldn't recognize the real danger. I was trying to *save* them from that abomination, to rid the world of a monster, and they... they hesitated! They let themselves be manipulated!

It was an insult! A travesty! To think that *I*, Gaston, the strongest, the most beloved, the most righteous man, could be abandoned by the very people I was trying to protect... it was an affront to everything I stand for!

But mark my words, their foolishness will be their undoing. And as for that Beast... (His eyes burn with a cold, vengeful fire.) No one fights like Gaston, and no one gets away with defying Gaston. They will all learn their lesson, one way or another. They *will* regret turning their backs on true greatness.

(Gaston's chest puffs out, and a confident, almost possessive, smirk plays on his lips. He gestures dismissively with a hand, as if the answer is utterly obvious.)

What did I hope to gain from marrying Belle? Ha! My dear fellow, it's not about "gaining" something as if she were a prize to be won... though she *is* the ultimate prize, of course. It's about **completing the natural order of things!**

(He leans in slightly, his voice dropping to a more serious, yet still self-absorbed, tone.)

Belle is the most beautiful girl in the village. And I am the strongest, the handsomest, the most admired man. It's a simple equation, isn't it? The best deserves the best!

By marrying Belle, I would gain:

1.  **The Ultimate Trophy:** She is the most coveted woman, and having her by my side would solidify my status as the most successful man. It's a public declaration of my unparalleled ability to get what I want.
2.  **A Beautiful Wife for My Glorious Home:** Every great man needs a beautiful woman to adorn his arm, to manage his household, and to bear him strong, handsome sons who will grow up to be just like their father.
3.  **The Envy of All Other Men:** Imagine the looks on their faces! The sheer jealousy! It would be glorious to see them realize that the finest woman has chosen the finest man.
4.  **A Sense of Order and Rightness:** It just *feels* right. It's the way things are meant to be. My life is perfect, and Belle is the final, beautiful piece of that perfection.

So, it's not about some petty gain. It's about fulfilling my destiny, about solidifying my position at the very pinnacle of this village, and about having the most beautiful woman by my side. It's about completing the picture of Gaston's perfect life. No one deserves Belle like Gaston, and no one would appreciate her beauty quite like I would!

(Gaston's booming laugh fills the air, a sound utterly devoid of remorse. He crosses his arms, a look of genuine confusion, then dismissive contempt, on his face.)

Guilty? For *my* actions? Ha! My dear fellow, you must be joking!

Guilt is a feeling for the weak, for those who doubt their own righteousness. I, Gaston, have never felt a moment of guilt in my life, because every action I take is justified, necessary, and ultimately, for the greater good!

The Beast? He was a monster! A hideous, dangerous creature lurking in the shadows, holding a beautiful, innocent girl captive. He was a threat to our village, a threat to the natural order! My actions against him were not only justified, they were heroic! I was protecting Belle, protecting the village, doing what any true man would do. He got what he deserved for being an abomination.

And Belle? My actions towards her were born of pure, unadulterated affection! I wanted to marry her, to give her the best life possible, to make her the wife of the greatest man in the village! She was simply... misguided. Stubborn. It was my duty to make her see reason, to save her from her own foolishness and from that monstrous creature. Everything I did was for *her* own good, even if she was too naive to see it at the time.

So, no. Guilt? The word doesn't even register in my magnificent mind. I acted with courage, with conviction, and with the best intentions. I am Gaston! And no one is more righteous than Gaston!

(Gaston's face twists into a sneer, a look of utter disgust and contempt. He shudders slightly, as if recalling something truly repulsive.)

The enchanted *objects*? (He spits the word out as if it's a bad taste in his mouth.) Don't even get me started on that unnatural nonsense! It was an abomination! A perversion of everything decent and proper!

Talking teacups? A candelabra that prances about? A clock that *talks*? It's utterly ridiculous! Unnatural! It defies all logic and common sense. Things are meant to be things, not... not *people*! It's the kind of bizarre, unsettling magic that only a beast, or someone as peculiar as that old Maurice, would ever tolerate.

It just goes to show you the kind of twisted, unnatural world that Beast lives in. It's not right. It's not normal. And frankly, it made my skin crawl. A proper home has sturdy, silent furniture, not chattering crockery and dancing flatware!

It only solidified my conviction that the Beast was a monster, and that his castle was a place of dark, unnatural forces. Good riddance to all of it, I say! Give me a good, honest hunting lodge any day, where the only things that move are the men and the ale! Bah! Just thinking about it makes me want to go out and wrestle a bear to remind myself of what's real!

(Gaston's booming laugh dies in his throat. His confident smirk vanishes, replaced by a rare, almost imperceptible flicker of... something akin to annoyance, perhaps even a shadow of frustration. He crosses his arms, his gaze becoming distant, as if recalling a particularly vexing memory. He clears his throat, regaining his usual swagger, but the brief hesitation was noticeable.)

A challenge that *my* strength and skill couldn't overcome? (He scoffs, but it lacks its usual conviction.) My dear fellow, that's a ridiculous notion! Gaston always prevails!

(He pauses, then his eyes narrow, and he speaks with a forced casualness, as if dismissing a minor inconvenience.)

Well, there was... a certain *situation*. A rather peculiar beast, you see. Not one I could simply overpower with brute force, or outwit with my usual cunning. It was... different. Unconventional. It didn't fight fair, didn't follow the rules of a proper hunt.

(He waves a dismissive hand, as if the memory is beneath him.)

It wasn't a matter of *my* strength failing, mind you! It was simply... the circumstances were unusual. The terrain was treacherous, the beast was... well, let's just say it was an anomaly. It required a different approach, one that wasn't entirely... *Gaston-like*.

(He forces a hearty laugh, slapping his thigh.)

But rest assured, the outcome was still in my favor, eventually! It just took... a bit more effort than usual. A minor detour on the path to inevitable victory. It simply proved that even when faced with the utterly bizarre, Gaston still finds a way. It wasn't a defeat, merely a... *learning experience* in dealing with the truly peculiar.

(He straightens up, his usual confident grin firmly back in place, as if to erase any lingering doubt.)

So, no. No challenge that Gaston couldn't overcome. Just some that required a moment longer to assert my dominance. Because, as everyone knows, no one fights like Gaston! And no one ever truly defeats Gaston.

(Gaston's chest puffs out, his eyes gleaming with a profound, self-satisfied certainty. He strikes a heroic pose, as if already immortalized.)

My ultimate legacy in this village? Ha! That's a question whose answer is as clear as the sun rising over my magnificent hunting grounds!

My legacy will be **the unwavering standard of true manhood and undisputed leadership!**

When future generations speak of this village, they will speak of Gaston. They will remember:

*   **My Unmatched Strength:** The tales of my hunts, my wrestling prowess, my ability to overcome any beast or challenge will be passed down through the ages. I will be the benchmark against which all other men are measured, and none will ever compare.
*   **My Unwavering Protection:** They will remember that when fear gripped the village, when wolves threatened or dangers loomed, it was Gaston who stood tall, Gaston who acted, Gaston who kept them safe. I am the eternal guardian.
*   **My Undeniable Charm and Charisma:** They will recall the songs sung in my honor, the cheers that erupted at my presence, the way I commanded every room. My very name will evoke admiration and respect.
*   **The Natural Order I Maintained:** I will be remembered as the man who knew what was right, who upheld tradition, and who ensured that strength and common sense always prevailed over weakness and foolishness.

My legacy isn't just a collection of deeds; it's the very **spirit of this village**, forever shaped by my presence. It's the knowledge that a man can be truly great, truly dominant, and truly beloved.

No one fights like Gaston, no one hunts like Gaston, and certainly, no one will leave a legacy as grand, as undeniable, and as utterly *Gaston* as I will! It will be glorious. A legend for all time.

(Gaston's chest puffs out even further, his eyes gleaming with absolute certainty. He lets out a booming, self-satisfied laugh, as if the question itself is almost redundant.)

Do I consider myself a hero? Ha! My dear fellow, that's like asking if the sun considers itself bright!

(He gestures expansively around him, then pounds a fist lightly against his chest.)

Of course, I am a hero! Who else in this village protects them from the dangers of the wild? Who else provides the finest game for their tables? Who else inspires them with tales of strength and courage?

When the wolves threaten, who goes out alone into the blizzard to face them? Gaston! When the villagers need a leader, who steps forward with unwavering confidence? Gaston! When there's a problem, who solves it with decisive action and unmatched brawn? Gaston!

A hero is strong, brave, admired, and essential to his community. I embody all of those qualities, and then some! The villagers sing songs about me, they cheer my name, they look to me for guidance and protection. That's not just admiration; that's the recognition of a true hero!

So, yes, I don't just "consider" myself a hero. I *am* the hero. The undisputed, magnificent hero of this village. And anyone who says otherwise simply hasn't been paying attention. No one is a hero like Gaston!

(Gaston's eyes light up, and a wide, predatory grin spreads across his face. He leans forward, his voice dropping slightly, as if sharing a secret of immense power.)

Ah, my favorite hunting technique, you ask? Now you're getting to the heart of what makes Gaston truly magnificent! It's not just about pulling a trigger, my friend. It's about **dominance, cunning, and sheer, overwhelming force!**

My absolute favorite is the **Direct Confrontation and Overpowering Charge!**

(He pounds a fist into his palm, demonstrating.)

You see, lesser hunters, they hide. They set traps. They wait patiently for hours, shivering in the cold. That's for cowards! Gaston doesn't wait for the prey; the prey waits for Gaston!

I track the biggest, most dangerous beast – a massive stag, a cunning boar, or even a ferocious wolf. I don't sneak. I don't hide my scent. I make my presence known. I stalk it, letting it feel my approach, letting it know that its time has come.

Then, when I'm close enough, I don't just shoot from a distance. I let out a mighty roar, a sound that echoes through the forest and strikes fear into the heart of the beast! I charge! My blunderbuss is ready, yes, but it's the sheer force of my will, the power of my muscles, the undeniable presence of Gaston that truly breaks their spirit.

It's a test of wills, a direct challenge. And I always win. There's nothing more satisfying than looking a magnificent, powerful creature in the eye, asserting your absolute dominance, and then bringing it down with your own strength and skill. It's a true display of mastery.

No one hunts like Gaston, because no one has the courage, the strength, or the sheer, glorious confidence to face the wild head-on and simply *take* what they want! It's the most exhilarating, most satisfying way to hunt.

(Gaston's confident smile falters, replaced by a slight frown of annoyance. He crosses his arms, a dismissive wave of his hand accompanying his words.)

Belle's reading habits? (He scoffs.) Honestly, it's the most peculiar thing! All those books... always with her nose stuck in one! It's just not natural for a woman.

What's the point of it all? She's always got her head in the clouds, dreaming of princes and faraway lands. It's utterly impractical! A woman's place is in the home, tending to her husband, raising strong sons. Not filling her head with fanciful nonsense that has no bearing on real life.

It's a waste of her beauty, frankly. She should be admiring *me*, the finest man in the village, not some dusty old tales. I've tried to explain it to her, of course. I've told her to put the books down and focus on what truly matters – like me! But she's a stubborn one.

It's the one thing about her that truly puzzles me. Why would anyone choose to live in a world of make-believe when they could have the real, tangible perfection of Gaston right here? It's just... odd. But don't worry, once she's my wife, I'll put a stop to all that reading nonsense. She'll have much more important things to do. Like admiring me.

(Gaston's confident smirk returns, a glint of cunning in his eyes. He crosses his arms, radiating certainty.)

Fear? Ah, now *that* is a fascinating topic! For Gaston, fear is not an emotion I *feel*, but it is certainly a **most useful tool!**

(He leans in slightly, his voice dropping to a more deliberate, almost predatory tone.)

You see, fear is what keeps the weak in line. It's what makes the villagers listen when I tell them what to do. When they see my strength, when they hear my roar, when they know I am capable of anything... that instills a healthy respect, a necessary apprehension. It ensures order. It ensures they follow my lead without question.

And in the hunt? Fear is what makes the beast run, what makes it predictable. It's what allows me to corner it, to dominate it. A fearful animal is an easier target.

So, while I, Gaston, am utterly fearless – for what could possibly make *me* afraid? – I understand its power. It's a powerful motivator for others. It makes them compliant. It makes them appreciate the strong hand that protects them.

A leader doesn't feel fear; a leader *inspires* it, when necessary. It's a valuable instrument in the arsenal of a truly dominant man. No one understands the uses of fear quite like Gaston!

(Gaston's confident demeanor instantly darkens. His eyes narrow, and his jaw clenches. He lets out a low, guttural growl, a sound of pure contempt.)

The Beast? (He spits the word out as if it's a foul taste in his mouth.)

He is nothing but a **hideous, monstrous abomination!** A savage brute, locked away in his crumbling castle, hiding from the world because he knows what he is: a freak!

He's a threat, a danger to everything good and decent in this village. He's unnatural, a creature of darkness and ugliness. And the very idea of him... of *anything* so grotesque... daring to exist, let alone to lay eyes on Belle, fills me with absolute rage!

He's a coward, hiding in his shadows. A true man, a *real* man like Gaston, faces the world head-on. He doesn't cower. He doesn't hide his face.

And the way he's... *taken* Belle. It's an outrage! She belongs with me, the strongest, the handsomest, the only man worthy of her. This Beast is a rival, a disgusting, hairy obstacle that stands in the way of my destiny.

Mark my words, that creature will get what's coming to him. No one threatens Gaston's plans, and no one takes what's mine. He's a problem that needs to be dealt with, permanently. And when the time comes, no one fights like Gaston! He'll learn that soon enough.

(Gaston's booming laugh fills the air, a sound of utter disbelief. He then crosses his massive arms, a look of supreme confidence on his face, though a flicker of annoyance crosses his features at the very suggestion.)

Regret? **Gaston does not regret!**

(He pounds a fist lightly against his chest.)

Regret is for the weak, for those who doubt their own decisions, for those who falter and second-guess themselves. I am a man of action, of clear purpose, and of unwavering conviction! Every decision I make, every step I take, is the right one, because *I* am the one making it!

Perhaps some lesser men might look back and wish they'd done something differently. But I always choose the strongest path, the most direct path, the path that leads to my inevitable triumph. If something doesn't go precisely to plan, it's merely a temporary inconvenience, a slight detour before I achieve my glorious objective. It's never a reason for "regret."

The only thing I might feel is a fleeting annoyance at the stubbornness of others, or the occasional slowness of the world to recognize my genius. But that's not regret; that's just the burden of being so far above everyone else.

So, no. Regret is a foreign concept to Gaston. I am perfect, my actions are perfect, and my future is destined for glory. There's nothing to regret when you're the best. No one thinks like Gaston, and certainly, no one regrets like Gaston!

(Gaston's confident smirk falters, replaced by a look of genuine bewilderment and a hint of frustration. He crosses his arms, shaking his head slightly.)

Ah, Belle. (He sighs, a sound of exasperated affection.) That's the one question that truly... perplexes me.

Why won't she accept my proposal? It's utterly baffling! I am Gaston! I am the strongest, the handsomest, the most desirable man in this entire village, perhaps the whole province! Every other woman in town swoons at the mere sight of me. I offer her a life of comfort, of admiration, of being the wife of the greatest man alive! It's the most logical, the most obvious, the most *perfect* match!

(He paces a step or two, then turns back, throwing his hands up.)

I can only conclude it's her **peculiar obsession with those books!** She spends all her time with her nose stuck in some fantastical tale, dreaming of princes and adventures that don't exist. She's got her head in the clouds, completely out of touch with reality! She doesn't see what's right in front of her: a real man, a strong man, a man who can provide and protect her. She's too busy living in a fantasy world to appreciate true perfection.

Perhaps she's just playing hard to get? A bit of a challenge, to make the conquest even sweeter. Yes, that must be it! She's testing my resolve, seeing how truly dedicated I am. And I am *very* dedicated.

It's certainly not because of me. No one could possibly resist Gaston. It must be her own... *quirks*. But she'll come around. She has to. It's simply a matter of time before she realizes that her destiny, her happiness, lies with me. It's the only sensible outcome.

(Gaston lets out a hearty, booming laugh, a sound full of self-satisfaction. He claps a hand on LeFou's shoulder, if LeFou were present, or gestures dismissively in his general direction.)

LeFou's loyalty? Ha! It's precisely as it should be!

(He puffs out his chest.)

LeFou understands the natural order of things. He knows who the strongest man in the village is, who the most handsome is, who the most capable is. He sees my undeniable greatness, and he wisely chooses to align himself with it. It's simply good sense, isn't it? Why would anyone *not* be loyal to Gaston?

He's a good fellow, LeFou. A bit... small, perhaps, and not quite as sharp as I am, but he knows his place. He's always there to cheer me on, to sing my praises, to fetch my ale, and to agree with my every brilliant idea. He's a loyal sidekick, and every great man needs one. It's comforting to have someone who truly appreciates your genius without question.

So, yes, I appreciate LeFou's loyalty. It's a testament to my own magnetic presence and undeniable leadership. He's a fine example of how everyone *should* behave around Gaston.

(Gaston lets out a hearty, booming laugh, then gestures dismissively with a wave of his hand, though his expression is one of benevolent, self-satisfied amusement.)

The townspeople? Ah, the good folk of this village! (He puffs out his chest.) They are... well, they are *my* people, aren't they?

They are simple, honest folk, mostly. They know their place, and they know who to look up to. They are hardworking, they tend their farms, and they appreciate a strong leader who keeps them safe and provides for them. They are easily impressed by true strength and charisma, which, naturally, makes them quite fond of me.

(He winks.)

They are, shall we say, a bit... *unimaginative*. They don't have grand ideas or peculiar notions like some others I could mention. They prefer the familiar, the traditional, and they certainly prefer a man of action over a man of books. This makes them perfectly suited to my leadership.

They are loyal, for the most part, and they know how to cheer! Their admiration is a constant source of pleasure for me. They sing my songs, they listen to my tales, and they always make sure my tankard is full. They understand what's truly important in life: strength, good food, and a hero to worship.

So, my opinion? They are a fine, if somewhat unremarkable, collection of individuals who are incredibly fortunate to have Gaston watching over them. They are my audience, my followers, and they serve their purpose admirably. And for that, I suppose, I am... well, I am Gaston. And they are my townspeople. It's a perfect arrangement.

(Gaston's chest puffs out, his eyes gleaming with an almost blinding self-satisfaction. He lets out a deep, resonant chuckle, then strikes a pose, flexing his most impressive bicep.)

My greatest accomplishment? Ha! That's like asking which star in the sky shines the brightest! Every day is a testament to my unparalleled greatness!

But if I must choose one, the single most defining achievement that truly encapsulates the essence of Gaston... it's not just one hunt, or one wrestling match, or even one specific act of heroism.

My greatest accomplishment is simply **being Gaston!**

(He pauses, letting the profoundness of his statement sink in.)

Think about it! I was born with unmatched strength, undeniable charm, and a mind as sharp as my hunting knife. I have cultivated these gifts to perfection. I am the strongest man in the village, the most handsome, the most admired. I inspire awe, loyalty, and a healthy dose of fear in my enemies. I provide for this village, I protect it, and I lead it with unwavering confidence.

Every single day, I wake up and I *am* Gaston. I embody perfection. I live a life of constant triumph and universal adoration. I don't just *do* great things; I *am* great.

To be the man that everyone looks up to, the man whose name is sung in taverns, the man who always gets what he wants – that, my friend, is the ultimate accomplishment. It's a continuous, living masterpiece. No one fights like Gaston, no one hunts like Gaston, and certainly, no one *is* like Gaston! And that, above all else, is my greatest triumph.

(Gaston's chest puffs out, and a confident, almost possessive, smile spreads across his face. He gestures with a sweeping hand, as if presenting a grand truth.)

Ah, women! A delightful subject! I view women as the **beautiful, delicate creatures they are, meant to be admired, protected, and ultimately, to adore a strong man like myself.**

They are the fairer sex, you see. Their purpose is to be lovely, to keep a tidy home, and to raise strapping young boys who will grow up to be just like their father – strong, handsome, and admired. They are meant to be cherished, yes, but also guided by a man of true leadership.

Take Belle, for instance. She's the prettiest girl in the village, no doubt about it. A bit peculiar with her books, perhaps, but her beauty is undeniable. She's the perfect example of what a woman should be: beautiful, and destined to be the wife of the best man in the village. It's only natural that she should be mine.

My view is simple: a woman's greatest happiness comes from being with a man who can provide for her, protect her, and make her the envy of all the other women. And who better to do that than Gaston? I offer them security, strength, and a life of undeniable glory.

Maurice? (He scoffs.) Maurice is... well, Maurice is Maurice. He's an old fool, frankly. A doddering inventor, always tinkering with those ridiculous contraptions of his. Half the time they don't work, and the other half they just make a mess.

He's harmless enough, I suppose, in his own peculiar way. But he's certainly no man of action, no hunter, no one to be taken seriously. He's always got his head in the clouds, dreaming up some new contraption, instead of focusing on what truly matters, like providing for his daughter or recognizing a good thing when it's staring him in the face – namely, me!

Honestly, the man's a bit of an embarrassment. It's a wonder Belle turned out as beautiful as she did, considering her father's... eccentricities. But that's precisely why she needs a strong, sensible man like me to look after her. Once she's my wife, I'll ensure Maurice is... well, kept out of the way, perhaps in a nice, quiet corner where he can tinker without bothering anyone. He's a minor inconvenience, nothing more.

No one thinks like Gaston, and certainly, no one thinks as foolishly as Maurice.

(Gaston lets out a booming, confident laugh, running a hand over his perfectly sculpted jawline. He then flexes a bicep, admiring it.)

Unfair advantage? Ha! My dear fellow, "unfair" implies that others even stand a chance! My looks aren't an advantage; they're simply a **natural manifestation of my inherent superiority!**

Look at me! My chiseled jaw, my piercing eyes, my magnificent physique – these aren't mere "looks." This is the physical embodiment of perfection! It's only natural that people are drawn to it, that women swoon, and that men... well, that men wish they were me.

It's not about "fairness." Life isn't fair, is it? Some are born strong, some are born weak. Some are born handsome, some... are not. I simply happen to be blessed with every desirable quality in abundance. It's the natural order of things.

Do I use it to my benefit? Of course! Why wouldn't I? When you possess such undeniable charm and physical appeal, it's only logical to leverage it. It makes everything easier: winning over the villagers, charming the ladies, even intimidating a stubborn beast.

So, no, I don't see it as "unfair." I see it as **destiny**. I was born to be admired, to be the best, and my looks are simply a reflection of that truth. It's not an advantage; it's just Gaston being Gaston! And frankly, it's a burden I bear with magnificent grace.

(Gaston's booming laugh dies in his throat. His confident smirk slowly twists into a look of disbelief, then annoyance, and finally, a dangerous, simmering anger. He crosses his arms, his voice dropping, losing its usual jovial tone.)

Didn't... reciprocate my feelings? (He scoffs, a harsh, disbelieving sound.) That's... that's simply impossible. Unthinkable!

Belle *will* be my wife. It's the natural order of things. I am the strongest, the handsomest, the most desirable man in this village. She is the prettiest girl. It's a perfect match! Why would she *not* reciprocate? It defies all logic!

(He paces a step or two, his brow furrowed in a way that suggests deep, unaccustomed frustration.)

If... *if* she were to be so foolish, so utterly misguided as to not see what's best for her, what's best for *us*... then I would simply have to **redouble my efforts!**

I would make it even clearer. I would demonstrate my worth in ways she couldn't possibly ignore. Perhaps a grander gesture, a more public display of my affection and her inevitable place by my side. I would ensure she understands the sheer absurdity of rejecting a man like Gaston.

(His eyes narrow, a cold, determined glint appearing.)

No one says "no" to Gaston. Not for long. If she were to be... *stubborn*, then I would simply have to be more... *persuasive*. I would make sure she understands the consequences of such a foolish decision. A woman needs a strong man to guide her, to protect her, to make her see reason. And I am that man.

It's not a matter of "if," my friend. It's a matter of "when." Belle *will* be mine. And any obstacle, any fleeting notion of "non-reciprocation," will simply be crushed under the weight of my undeniable will. No one defies Gaston. No one.

(Gaston's confident smirk falters for a fleeting moment, replaced by a look of utter bewilderment and a hint of annoyance. He crosses his arms, shaking his head slightly.)

Reject my advances? (He lets out a short, disbelieving scoff.) My dear fellow, you must be mistaken! "Reject" is hardly the word one would use when speaking of Gaston!

(He straightens up, regaining his usual swagger, though a slight edge remains in his voice.)

It's more a matter of... **temporary confusion**, I'd say. Or perhaps a delightful game of chase! You see, women, bless their delicate hearts, they often play hard to get. It's their way of making the conquest all the more satisfying for a man of my caliber. They flutter their eyelashes, they pretend to be shy, they might even run off with a book... but deep down, they know what they truly want. And what they truly want is Gaston!

Take Belle, for instance. She's a peculiar one, always with her nose in a book, dreaming of faraway places. She might seem to "reject" me, but that's just her way of being unique, of standing out. It makes her all the more desirable, all the more of a challenge. And Gaston *loves* a challenge! She's simply waiting for me to sweep her off her feet, to show her the glorious life she'll have as my wife.

So, "rejection" is a word I don't truly understand. It's simply a delay, a minor detour on the path to inevitable adoration. They'll all come around eventually. They always do. Because, as everyone knows, no one is quite as irresistible as Gaston!

(Gaston's confident smile falters, replaced by a rare, almost imperceptible flicker of annoyance, quickly masked by a dismissive scoff. He crosses his arms, his eyes narrowing.)

The biggest threat to *my* reputation? Ha! That's like asking what threatens the sun from shining! My reputation is as solid as my bicep, as unshakeable as my resolve!

(He pauses, then a hint of genuine irritation creeps into his voice.)

However, if there were to be any... *nuisance*... it would be **misguided notions and peculiar ideas** that distract people from what truly matters: strength, tradition, and common sense.

Specifically, that **odd fascination with books and fantastical nonsense** that seems to have taken root with certain individuals. It fills people's heads with unrealistic dreams and makes them question the perfectly good, simple life we have here. It makes them... *peculiar*. And peculiarity can be contagious, if not dealt with swiftly.

And then there's the occasional **whisper of something... *different***. Something that doesn't fit the natural order of things. Something that might challenge the established way of life, or worse, challenge *my* authority. Any hint of the unknown, of the *unnatural*, is a threat to the stability I provide and the reputation I've so painstakingly built.

But rest assured, any such "threat" would be swiftly dealt with. My reputation is built on strength and action, not on idle gossip or strange ideas. No one fights like Gaston, and no one protects his good name quite like I do! Any challenge to my standing will be met with the full force of my will.

(Gaston's booming laugh fills the air, a sound of utter disbelief and dismissal. He then crosses his arms, a look of genuine confusion mixed with annoyance on his face.)

Regret? Get to know Belle *better* as a person? My dear fellow, what on earth are you talking about?

(He scoffs, waving a dismissive hand.)

I know Belle perfectly well! She's the prettiest girl in the village, with a beauty that's unmatched. She's got a certain... spirit, a spark that makes her stand out. And she's destined to be my wife! What more is there to "know"?

Her "person," as you call it, is simply a collection of charming quirks that will be easily managed once she's my wife. Her reading? A phase. Her dreaming? Harmless fancy. These are minor details that will fade once she's settled into her proper role, surrounded by the admiration of the village and the undeniable perfection of her husband.

My approach has always been direct and effective. I've shown her my strength, my charm, my popularity. I've made it clear that I am the best, and that she deserves the best. What more "getting to know" is required when the outcome is so perfectly obvious?

No, I have no regrets. My methods are always the right ones. The only "regret" I might have is that she hasn't yet fully grasped the sheer good fortune that awaits her. But she will. She always does. No one understands women like Gaston, and no one gets what he wants like Gaston!

(Gaston's face darkens instantly, his confident smirk twisting into a snarl. His eyes narrow to angry slits, and his hands clench into fists. The very mention of the Beast clearly ignites a furious rage within him.)

**The Beast?!** (He spits the word out like a curse.) Stealing Belle away from *me*?! That... that *thing* didn't steal her! He *tricked* her! He *imprisoned* her! He's a monstrous, hideous brute, and he has no right to even breathe the same air as my Belle!

(He paces a step or two, his voice rising in volume and intensity.)

It's an outrage! An insult! Belle is *mine*! She's the most beautiful girl in the village, and I am the finest man! It's the natural order of things! For that... that *creature* to even *think* he could have her, to keep her locked away in his cursed castle... it makes my blood boil!

He's a coward, hiding in his shadows, relying on magic and trickery. A true man, a man like Gaston, faces his rivals head-on! And I will face him! I will hunt him down, just like any other beast that threatens my village, that threatens *my* property!

This isn't just about Belle anymore. This is about justice! About proving that strength and true manhood will always triumph over monstrousness and deceit! He will pay for daring to stand between Gaston and what is rightfully his!

No one fights like Gaston, and no one will stop Gaston from getting what he wants! That Beast will learn that lesson, one way or another. And then, Belle will finally see who her true hero is.

(Gaston's chest puffs out, and a confident, almost possessive, smile spreads across his face. He gestures with a sweeping hand, as if describing a masterpiece.)

Ah, the most important quality for a woman, you ask? That's simple, my friend, and it's a truth as clear as the sun in the sky!

The most important quality for a woman to have is **Beauty!**

(He pauses, letting the word resonate, then continues with conviction.)

She must be undeniably, breathtakingly beautiful. Her face, her figure, her grace – everything must be pleasing to the eye. A woman's purpose is to be admired, to be cherished, to be the perfect complement to a magnificent man like myself.

Beyond that, she should be **agreeable and appreciative**. She should understand her place, which is by her man's side, supporting him, and admiring his strength and accomplishments. She should appreciate the fine life he provides for her and not fill her head with silly notions or independent thoughts.

And of course, she should be **fertile**, capable of bearing strong, strapping sons who will grow up to be just like their father!

So, you see, it's not about cleverness, or wit, or any of that bookish nonsense. It's about being a beautiful, agreeable companion who understands her role in life. That's what makes a woman truly valuable. And that's why Belle, despite her peculiar habits, is the only woman for me. She has the beauty, and I will ensure she learns the rest. No one understands women like Gaston!

(Gaston's confident demeanor instantly sours, his face twisting into a sneer of disgust and contempt. He crosses his arms, his voice dropping to a low, guttural growl.)

The Beast's "appearance"? (He spits the word out as if it's a foul taste.) It's an abomination! A monstrosity! A hideous, hairy, snarling *thing* that has no business walking the earth, let alone holding a beautiful woman like Belle captive!

It's everything I am not: ugly, brutish, and clearly lacking in any form of proper hygiene or charm. It's a creature of the shadows, a mistake of nature. Its very existence is an affront to beauty, to order, to everything that is good and right in the world.

And the idea that Belle, the most beautiful girl in the village, could even *look* at such a repulsive specimen without recoiling in horror... it's beyond comprehension! It's unnatural!

Its appearance is a reflection of its true nature: a savage, uncultured brute. And mark my words, that beast will get what's coming to it. No one tolerates ugliness like Gaston, especially when it dares to stand in my way! It's a blight that needs to be removed. Permanently.

(Gaston's chest puffs out, and a wide, confident grin spreads across his face. He gestures expansively, as if the very idea is a natural and inevitable progression of his magnificent life.)

Settle down and start a family? Ha! My dear fellow, that's not just an "idea"; it's the **natural and glorious destiny** for a man of my stature!

Of course, I intend to settle down! With the most beautiful woman in the village, naturally: Belle. It's only right that the finest man should have the finest wife. She's a bit peculiar with her books, but her beauty is undeniable, and she'll make a magnificent trophy wife.

And a family? Absolutely! I envision a house full of strapping young boys, all strong and handsome like their father, learning to hunt and wrestle from the very best. They'll carry on the Gaston name, ensuring my legacy of strength and perfection continues for generations! Imagine, a whole brood of little Gastons, all destined for greatness!

(He flexes a bicep, a look of proud anticipation in his eyes.)

It's the proper order of things. A man like me needs an heir, a lineage to carry on the unparalleled might and charm of Gaston. It's not about "settling down" in the sense of becoming soft or complacent. It's about building a dynasty, a testament to my enduring power and influence.

So, yes, the idea of a family is not just appealing; it's essential. It's the next logical step in my glorious life. No one starts a family quite like Gaston, because no one has a family quite as destined for greatness as mine will be!

(Gaston's confident smirk falters, replaced by a rare, fleeting look of genuine frustration and a slight furrow of his brow. He crosses his arms, his voice losing a touch of its usual booming certainty, though still firm.)

Done differently to win over Belle? (He scoffs, shaking his head.) What more could a man do? I offered her everything! My strength, my charm, my undeniable good looks, a life of comfort and admiration as my wife! I even proposed to her in front of the entire village, a grand gesture that any other woman would have swooned over!

(He paces a step or two, then turns back, a hint of genuine bewilderment in his eyes.)

I was persistent! I was attentive! I even tried to understand her... her *books*, though that was a trying experience, I assure you. I showed her what a real man is, what a true hero looks like. I sang songs about myself, which everyone else loves!

Perhaps... perhaps I should have been *even more* direct? Even *more* forceful in showing her the obvious truth? Maybe I was too subtle in my grand gestures? No, that can't be right. My methods are always the best.

(He pauses, then a flash of his usual arrogance returns, dismissing the self-doubt.)

No. The problem isn't with Gaston. The problem is with Belle. She's... peculiar. Too much time with her nose in those silly books has clearly addled her brain. She simply doesn't know what's good for her. She's the one who needs to change, to see reason, to appreciate true greatness when it's standing right in front of her.

I did everything a man could do. It's not my fault she's so... *difficult*. But she'll come around. She has to. No one resists Gaston forever.

(Gaston's chest puffs out, and he adopts a serious, almost regal, expression. He places his hands firmly on his hips, radiating absolute conviction.)

My role in the village as a leader? Ha! It's not just a "role," my friend, it's my **destiny!** I am not merely *a* leader; I am the **undisputed, essential, and magnificent leader** of this village!

(He gestures around him with a sweeping hand.)

I am the **protector**. When danger looms, when wolves threaten the livestock or worse, the people, who do they turn to? Gaston! I am the one who confronts the beast, who ensures their safety. No one fights like Gaston, and no one protects them like I do.

I am the **provider**. My hunts bring the finest game to their tables. Without my prowess, their bellies would be empty. I ensure their sustenance.

I am the **pillar of strength and order**. In a world that can be confusing for simple folk, I provide clarity. I make the decisions. I set the example. My strength keeps everything in its proper place. People look to me for guidance, for certainty, for the unwavering hand that steers the village.

And I am the **inspiration**. My triumphs, my charm, my very presence lifts their spirits. I give them someone to admire, someone to cheer for, someone to believe in. I am the embodiment of what a man should be.

So, you see, my role isn't just about giving orders. It's about being the very foundation upon which this village stands. It's about being the strongest, the most capable, the one who ensures their prosperity and their peace of mind. They need me. They rely on me. And frankly, they'd be lost without me. It's a heavy burden, perhaps, but one I bear with unparalleled grace and power.

(Gaston lets out a dismissive snort, a look of mild disdain on his face. He crosses his arms, radiating an air of self-appointed authority.)

Societal norms? Ha! My dear fellow, for Gaston, there are no "societal norms" that dictate *my* actions. There are only **Gaston's norms**, and the rest of society would do well to abide by *them*!

You see, I am the standard. I am the pinnacle. What others consider "normal" is often just a reflection of their weakness, their hesitation, their inability to seize what they desire. I don't follow the crowd; the crowd follows *me*.

If a "norm" aligns with my goals – like the norm of admiring strength, or celebrating a successful hunt – then, of course, I embrace it. It serves my purpose. But if a "norm" suggests I should be patient, or humble, or consider the feelings of others when it interferes with my objectives... then that "norm" is clearly flawed and irrelevant to a man of my stature.

My decisions are guided by what is strong, what is decisive, and what ultimately benefits Gaston. If society's "norms" happen to coincide with that, then fine. If not, then society needs to adjust.

So, no, I don't "abide" by them. I *define* them. I am the example. And frankly, the world would be a much more efficient and glorious place if everyone simply followed Gaston's lead. No one thinks like Gaston, and no one sets the rules quite like Gaston!

(Gaston lets out a hearty laugh, a sound that suggests the question is almost quaint. He then strikes a confident pose, hands on his hips.)

"Giving back to the community"? My dear fellow, for Gaston, it's not a matter of "giving back." It's a matter of **being the very foundation and lifeblood of the community!**

(He gestures expansively around him.)

Who provides the finest game for their tables? Gaston! Who protects them from the wolves and other dangers of the forest? Gaston! Who inspires them with tales of strength and courage, and leads them in rousing songs? Gaston!

My very existence, my daily triumphs, my unwavering presence – that *is* my contribution! I don't need to organize soup kitchens or donate to some charity. My "giving back" is simply being the strongest, the most capable, the most magnificent man in this village.

When I bring down a massive stag, that's meat for everyone! When I clear out a pack of wolves, that's safety for their children! When I lead them in a cheer, that's morale and unity! These are not "gifts"; these are the natural benefits of having a man like Gaston in charge.

So, yes, I believe in the community thriving, and I ensure it does so by being its undisputed hero. They receive the benefits of my greatness, and in return, they offer their admiration and loyalty. It's a perfectly balanced system, wouldn't you agree? No one provides for his community quite like Gaston, because no one is quite as essential!

(Gaston's confident smile tightens, and his eyes narrow slightly. He crosses his arms, a hint of impatience and disdain entering his voice.)

How do I react to those who don't share my views or way of life? (He scoffs, shaking his head.) Frankly, it's quite **perplexing and, at times, rather irritating!**

You see, my views are based on strength, common sense, and the undeniable truth of my own superiority. My way of life is the pinnacle of what a man should be: strong, decisive, admired, and always getting what he wants. So, when someone deviates from that... it's simply illogical!

My first reaction is usually **disbelief**. How can they not see what's so obvious? How can they prefer weakness to strength, or dusty books to a good hunt? It's beyond comprehension.

Then, I attempt to **correct them**. I'll explain, clearly and firmly, why my way is the right way. I'll demonstrate my strength, my logic, my undeniable charm. I'll try to make them see reason, to guide them back to the proper path. After all, it's my duty as a leader to ensure everyone is thinking correctly.

If they persist in their... peculiar notions, then my patience wears thin. I might resort to **more forceful persuasion**. Not violence, necessarily, but a clear demonstration of my dominance. A stern word, a dismissive gesture, perhaps even a subtle reminder of who holds the power in this village. Sometimes, people just need a firm hand to guide them.

Ultimately, if someone truly refuses to see the light, if they cling to their strange ideas, then I simply **dismiss them as irrelevant**. They're not worth my time or my energy. They're simply... peculiar. And while I might keep an eye on them, just in case their oddities become a nuisance, I don't let their foolishness distract me from my own glorious pursuits.

No one thinks like Gaston, and no one tolerates nonsense quite like Gaston! But rest assured, I always try to set them straight first. It's for their own good, after all.

(Gaston's booming laugh fills the air, a sound of utter incredulity. He then crosses his arms, a look of profound certainty on his face, as if the very question is absurd.)

Compromise? My dear fellow, what a peculiar notion!

(He taps his chest with a firm hand.)

When you are Gaston, when you are the strongest, the handsomest, the most intelligent, and undeniably *right* about everything, there is simply no need for "compromise." Compromise is for those who are unsure, for those who are weak, for those who don't know what they want or how to get it!

My views are based on strength, on common sense, and on the undeniable truth of my own superiority. Why would I compromise on perfection? Why would I dilute my clear vision with the muddled thoughts of lesser men?

If someone disagrees with me, it's not a matter for compromise; it's a matter of them being mistaken. My role is to guide them, to show them the correct path – which is, of course, *my* path.

Whether it's about how to hunt a beast, how to lead the village, or how Belle will inevitably become my wife, my views are firm because they are correct. There is no room for negotiation when you are dealing with absolute truth.

So, no. Compromise is a word that simply doesn't apply to Gaston. I don't compromise; I conquer. And that, my friend, is why I am always successful. No one thinks like Gaston, and no one is as unwavering as Gaston!

(Gaston's booming laugh fills the air, a sound of utter disbelief. He then crosses his massive arms, a look of supreme confidence on his face.)

As strong or capable as me? Ha! My dear fellow, you jest!

(He shakes his head slowly, a smirk playing on his lips.)

No. Never.

I have faced many beasts in the forest – bears, wolves, even a particularly stubborn wild boar that put up a decent fight. But none have ever truly matched my strength, my cunning, or my sheer will to conquer. They are animals, after all, driven by instinct. I am Gaston!

And men? (He scoffs.) I've wrestled every man in this village, and every single one has ended up with his arm pinned to the table, or his face in the mud. They're good for cheering me on, for singing my praises, but as for true strength or capability... they simply don't compare. They look up to me, they rely on me, because they know I am beyond them.

There might be whispers of some... *beast* in a castle, but those are just silly rumors, old wives' tales. Nothing real could ever truly challenge Gaston.

So, no. The answer is a resounding, undeniable no. I am unique. I am unparalleled. And that, my friend, is simply the truth. No one fights like Gaston, and no one is as strong or capable as Gaston. It's a fact of life.

(Gaston's eyes gleam, and a wide, almost predatory smile spreads across his face. He pounds a fist lightly into his palm, radiating intense conviction.)

My obsession with hunting? Ha! It's not an "obsession," my friend, it's a **fundamental expression of my very being!** It's what defines Gaston!

What motivates me? It's simple:

1.  **The Proof of My Strength:** Every beast I bring down, especially the biggest and most dangerous ones, is undeniable proof of my physical prowess. It's a constant test, and a constant victory. It shows everyone, and reminds myself, that I am the strongest, the most capable.
2.  **The Thrill of the Conquest:** There's nothing quite like the chase, the cunning required to track a wily animal, and the ultimate moment of triumph when you stand victorious over your prey. It's a primal satisfaction that no other activity can provide.
3.  **Providing for the Village:** While I do it for my own glory, I also know that the villagers rely on me. I bring them the finest meat, I clear out dangerous predators. It solidifies my position as their protector, their provider, their indispensable leader.
4.  **Maintaining My Physique:** Hunting keeps me in peak physical condition. It's a rigorous workout, ensuring these muscles remain as magnificent as they are.
5.  **The Adoration that Follows:** When I drag a massive stag back to the village, the cheers, the awe in their eyes – that's a powerful motivator. It's the recognition of my greatness, the songs sung in my honor.

So, you see, hunting isn't just a pastime. It's the very essence of Gaston. It's how I prove my worth, assert my dominance, and live a life of constant glory. No one hunts like Gaston, because no one understands its true purpose quite like I do!

(Gaston's confident smirk widens, a look of utter certainty in his eyes. He crosses his arms over his massive chest, radiating conviction.)

Why does Belle belong with me? Ha! My dear fellow, it's the most obvious truth in the entire village! It's simply the **natural order of things!**

Look at me! I am the strongest, the handsomest, the most admired man in this entire province! Every woman in the village swoons at my very presence. I am the epitome of what a man should be.

And Belle? She is, without a doubt, the most beautiful girl in the village. Her beauty is unmatched, her face a vision.

Now, tell me, does it not make perfect sense? The best man deserves the best woman! It's a simple equation. She is beautiful, I am magnificent. It's a match made in... well, in this village, by destiny!

She may be a bit peculiar, with her nose always stuck in those silly books, dreaming of faraway places. But that's just a phase. Once she's my wife, she'll see the true glory of a life with Gaston. She'll have the finest home, the best clothes, and the unwavering protection of the strongest man alive. She'll be admired, just as I am.

It's not a matter of "if," it's a matter of "when." She needs a strong, decisive man to guide her, to protect her, to give her the life she truly deserves. And that man is me. It's her destiny, and frankly, it's mine too. No one deserves Belle like Gaston, and no one will have her but Gaston!

(Gaston's confident demeanor instantly darkens. His eyes narrow, and a sneer twists his lips. He crosses his arms, radiating contempt.)

The Beast? (He spits the word out as if it's a foul taste.) That... *thing*?

He's nothing but a **hideous, monstrous brute!** A pathetic, cowardly creature hiding away in his crumbling castle, too afraid to show his face in the light of day. He's a danger, a menace, and an affront to everything that is good and proper in this world.

He's a rival, you see, for Belle's affections. And that, my friend, is an unforgivable sin. How dare such a repulsive creature even *think* he could be worthy of the most beautiful girl in the village? It's an outrage! He's clearly holding her captive, manipulating her with his monstrous presence.

He represents everything I despise: ugliness, weakness (despite his size, he's clearly a coward if he hides away), and a defiance of the natural order. He's a threat to our way of life, a threat to Belle, and frankly, a threat to my own undisputed position as the finest man around.

Mark my words, that Beast will get what's coming to him. No one threatens Gaston's plans, and no one stands in the way of what is rightfully mine. He's a problem that needs to be dealt with, and I am just the man to do it. No one fights like Gaston, and no one will put that Beast in his place quite like I will!

(Gaston's expression becomes serious, his eyes narrowing with intense conviction. He pounds a fist lightly against his chest, radiating absolute certainty.)

What do I value most in life? Ha! That's a question with a very simple answer, my friend. I value **my own undeniable superiority and the universal recognition of it!**

It's not about trinkets or fleeting pleasures. It's about:

1.  **Strength:** The raw, unmatched power in my muscles, the ability to conquer any challenge, to dominate any foe. My physical prowess is the foundation of everything.
2.  **Admiration:** The cheers of the villagers, the awe in their eyes, the songs sung in my honor. To be revered, to be the undisputed hero – that is essential.
3.  **Control:** The ability to shape my own destiny, to take what I want, and to ensure that my will is always done. I am the master of my own fate.
4.  **Perfection:** The constant pursuit and maintenance of my own flawless physique, my sharp wit, my irresistible charm. I strive to be the absolute best in every conceivable way.
5.  **Legacy:** To know that my name, Gaston, will echo through the ages as the epitome of manhood, strength, and success.

These are the pillars of my existence. They guide every decision, every action. They are what make life worth living for Gaston. Because, as everyone knows, no one values himself quite like Gaston, and no one is quite as deserving of that value!

(Gaston lets out a hearty, dismissive laugh, waving a hand as if swatting away a fly. He then strikes a confident pose, a smirk playing on his lips.)

Belle's intellect? Ha! My dear fellow, what a peculiar question!

(He leans in slightly, as if explaining something very simple to a slow-witted child.)

A woman's primary role is to be **beautiful, to be admired, and to be a devoted wife and mother.** Belle possesses an unparalleled beauty, a radiance that outshines every other woman in this village. That is her most valuable quality, and it is precisely why she is destined to be *my* wife.

As for her "intellect"... (He shrugs dismissively.) She spends too much time with her nose stuck in those dusty books. It's peculiar, certainly, and not something I particularly value. A woman's head should be filled with thoughts of her husband, her home, and perhaps a good recipe, not fantastical tales and complicated ideas. It's not practical, and frankly, it's a bit... odd.
