And as for "masculinity," what else is there? A man is strong, decisive, a hunter, a protector. Anything less is... well, it's not a man at all, is it? I simply embody what is right and proper. It's not an act; it's my very nature.

Perhaps you're confusing my natural confidence and dominance with some sort of insecurity. Let me assure you, there is no insecurity in Gaston! I simply believe in showing, not just telling, why I am the best. It's about setting the standard, about being the example for all others to aspire to.

So, it's not a "need to prove." It's a **duty to demonstrate**. A duty to show the world what true greatness looks like. Because, as everyone knows, no one fights like Gaston, and no one is quite as much of a man as Gaston!

(Gaston's chest puffs out, and a confident, almost possessive, smirk plays on his lips. He gestures with a sweeping hand, as if outlining a perfect picture.)

Ah, love and marriage! Now *this* is a topic I understand perfectly. For Gaston, it's not some complicated, mushy nonsense. It's about **order, beauty, and the natural pairing of the best with the best!**

Love, to me, is the undeniable admiration and devotion that a beautiful woman feels for a magnificent man. It's the recognition of true superiority. When Belle looks at me, she'll see strength, charm, and a secure future. That's love. It's not about silly feelings or shared interests; it's about recognizing what is clearly the best choice.

Marriage? That's the logical next step! It's about securing the prettiest girl in the village to be the wife of the finest man. It's about having a beautiful woman to admire you, to bear you strong sons, and to keep your home in order. It's a partnership, yes, but one where the roles are clear.

The ideal relationship dynamic is simple: **The man leads, and the woman admires and supports.**

*   **The Man (Me, naturally):** Provides, protects, makes all the important decisions, and is the undisputed head of the household. He is strong, confident, and always right. His word is law.
*   **The Woman (Belle, eventually):** Is beautiful, graceful, and devoted. Her role is to appreciate her husband's greatness, to ensure his comfort, and to raise strong, handsome children who will also admire their father. She doesn't need to think too much; her beauty and her devotion are her greatest assets.

It's a clear, sensible arrangement. It ensures harmony, stability, and the continuation of a strong lineage. Any other dynamic is just... peculiar. It's the natural order of things, and it's the only way a truly successful and happy marriage can exist. No one understands love and marriage quite like Gaston, because no one is quite as perfectly suited to it!

(Gaston's confident smirk doesn't waver, though his eyes hold a hint of genuine surprise at the question, as if the answer should be obvious. He lets out a hearty, dismissive laugh.)

"Show off"? "Exaggerate"? My dear fellow, you misunderstand! I don't "show off"; I simply **display my undeniable superiority!** And as for "exaggerating," I merely **state the glorious truth** of my accomplishments!

Why do I do it? Because it's my duty! It's what the people need!

(He pounds a fist lightly against his chest.)

How else are the villagers to know they have the strongest, the bravest, the most capable man protecting them? How else are they to feel safe, to feel inspired, to know that their leader is truly worthy of their admiration? My displays of strength and my tales of conquest aren't for my own vanity – though I admit, it *is* a magnificent sight – they are for the benefit of everyone!

When I tell a story of bringing down a beast, I'm not just recounting facts; I'm painting a picture of heroism, of a man who faces danger head-on and always triumphs. It gives them hope! It reminds them that no one fights like Gaston, and therefore, they are safe under my watchful eye.

And if a detail here or there is... shall we say, *enhanced* for dramatic effect? Well, that's simply good storytelling! It makes the legend even grander, even more inspiring. The truth is already magnificent, but a little polish makes it shine even brighter.

So, it's not about "showing off." It's about fulfilling my role as the village's hero, its protector, its undisputed champion. It's about reminding everyone, constantly, that they are blessed to have Gaston. It's for their benefit, truly!

(Gaston's confident smirk falters, replaced by a look of dismissive disdain. He scoffs, waving a dismissive hand.)

Supernatural? Magical elements? Ha! My dear fellow, those are just **fairy tales and parlor tricks for the weak-minded!** I deal in reality, in tangible strength, in what a man can achieve with his own two hands and a keen eye.

Magic is for those who lack true power. Why would I need some silly spell or a glowing wand when I have these muscles? (He flexes a bicep, then pounds his chest.) My strength is real. My aim is true. My charm is undeniable. These are facts, not some whimsical nonsense.

As for their relevance in the pursuit of power and dominance... (He lets out a derisive snort.) None whatsoever! True power comes from within. It comes from being the strongest, the most cunning, the most feared. It comes from inspiring awe and obedience through sheer force of will and physical prowess.

Anyone who relies on "magic" is simply admitting they're not strong enough on their own. They're a coward, hiding behind illusions. A real man, a true leader, doesn't need to conjure fire or turn people into frogs. He simply *takes* what he wants, by force if necessary, and commands respect through his own inherent superiority.

So, no. I have no time for such fanciful notions. They are irrelevant distractions. The only magic I believe in is the magic of being Gaston! And that, my friend, is more powerful than any spell. Now, let's talk about something substantial, shall we? Like my latest hunting triumph!

(Gaston's chest puffs out, and he lets out a hearty, booming laugh, as if the answer is so obvious it barely needs stating. He then strikes a classic heroic pose, flexing a bicep.)

Why is it important? My dear fellow, it's not just important, it's **essential!** It's the very foundation of order, respect, and a truly glorious life!

Look around you! In this world, a man's worth is measured by his brawn, his ability to provide, and his undeniable presence.

**Strength** is paramount! How else do you protect the village from wolves? How else do you bring down the biggest stag to feed the hungry? How else do you win every contest and prove your dominance? Strength commands respect. It ensures safety. It makes you the leader, the one everyone looks to when trouble arises. Without strength, you're just another weakling, easily pushed aside. No one fights like Gaston, and that's why I'm the one in charge!

And **handsomeness**? Well, that's simply the outward manifestation of inner perfection! It draws people to you, makes them admire you, makes them *want* to be around you. It's what makes the women swoon and the men wish they were half as magnificent. It's part of the package that makes me irresistible, that makes me the natural choice for the prettiest girl in town.

Together, strength and handsomeness create an aura of **undeniable superiority**. It means you get the best of everything. The best food, the best ale, the best woman. It means your word is law, and your presence commands attention. It's not about vanity; it's about the natural order of things. The best deserves the best, and I am clearly the best.

So, you see, it's not just about personal pride, though I have plenty of that. It's about being the pillar of the community, the protector, the provider, and the ultimate example of what a man should be. It's the only way to live a truly successful and glorious life!

(Gaston's confident smirk returns, but this time it's laced with a hint of disdain and utter certainty. He scoffs, crossing his massive arms.)

Why should Belle choose *me* over that... that *thing*? Ha! My dear fellow, the question itself is an insult to common sense! It's as plain as the nose on my face, which, I might add, is a perfectly sculpted, handsome nose!

First, look at me! (He gestures to his magnificent physique.) I am a **man!** A real man! Strong, handsome, virile, with a full head of hair and not a single beastly hair on my chin! I am the epitome of what a woman desires. What is *he*? A monstrous, hairy brute, locked away in a crumbling castle! He's a beast, for crying out loud!

Secondly, I am **known!** I am admired! I am the hero of this village! Everyone loves Gaston! Belle would be marrying the most popular, most respected man around. She'd be the envy of every woman, living a life of adoration and comfort, surrounded by people who cheer my name. What does *he* offer? A life of isolation with a growling monster!

Thirdly, I am **normal!** I am familiar! I am everything a woman needs in a husband. I'll provide, I'll protect, and I'll ensure she has a proper place in society, as my wife. He's... an abomination! A creature of darkness and mystery. Who knows what horrors lurk beneath that fur?

And finally, I am **Gaston!** No one fights like Gaston, no one hunts like Gaston, and no one loves Belle like Gaston! My intentions are clear, my devotion is absolute, and my future is glorious. She deserves the best, and the best is *me*. Not some cursed, ugly, ill-tempered animal.

It's not even a choice, really. It's a matter of simple, undeniable fact. Belle belongs with Gaston. It's the natural order of things.

(Gaston's booming laugh fills the air, a sound of genuine amusement at the question. He then strikes a confident pose, hands on his hips, a smirk playing on his lips.)

Care about anyone other than myself? My dear fellow, what a peculiar question!

(He gestures expansively around him, then points to his chest.)

Of course I do! I care about **Belle**, deeply! She is the most beautiful woman in the village, and she *will* be my wife. My entire future, my legacy, depends on her. I care about her happiness, her comfort, her future as Mrs. Gaston! It's only natural that the best man should care for the best woman.

And I care about **LeFou**! He's my loyal sidekick, my biggest fan. He ensures my ale is always full, my songs are always sung, and he's always there to cheer me on. A man needs a good follower, and LeFou is the best. I ensure he's well-fed and always by my side.

I also care about **this village**! Who else protects them from wolves? Who else provides them with the finest game? Who else inspires them with tales of strength and glory? They rely on me, and I ensure their safety and prosperity. It's my duty as their leader, and frankly, they'd be lost without me.

So, you see, it's not just about *me* in some isolated sense. My well-being, my glory, my happiness, are intrinsically linked to the well-being of those around me. Belle's beauty enhances my life, LeFou's loyalty supports me, and the villagers' admiration fuels me.

It's a grand ecosystem, you might say, with Gaston at the very center, ensuring everything runs smoothly and gloriously. So yes, I care. I care about the things and the people that contribute to the magnificent life of Gaston! No one cares quite like Gaston, because no one has such a perfect world to care for!

(Gaston's confident demeanor instantly darkens. His eyes narrow, and his jaw clenches. He lets out a low, guttural growl, a sound of pure contempt.)

The Beast? (He spits the word out as if it's a foul taste in his mouth.) That... *thing*?

He is an **abomination!** A monstrous, hideous brute, lurking in his crumbling castle, stealing away what is rightfully mine! He is everything I despise: ugly, reclusive, and clearly a danger to this village.

He has no place in a civilized world. He's a savage, a creature of the wild, and he dares to keep Belle, the most beautiful woman, locked away! It's an outrage! She belongs with me, the strongest, the handsomest, the *human* man who can protect her and give her the life she deserves.

He is a threat to everything I stand for: order, beauty, and the natural supremacy of man. He represents chaos, ugliness, and a challenge to my authority that cannot, *will not*, be tolerated.

Mark my words, that Beast will pay for his insolence. He will learn that no one fights like Gaston, and no one stands in Gaston's way. He is a problem that needs to be dealt with, permanently. And I am just the man to do it.

(Gaston's booming laugh fills the air, a sound utterly devoid of remorse. He crosses his arms, a look of genuine confusion, then dismissive arrogance, on his face.)

Regret? **Regret?!** My dear fellow, what in the blazes are you talking about? Gaston does not *regret*! Gaston acts! And every action I've taken has been for the good, for the right, for the preservation of order and common sense!

My actions towards Belle were nothing but the noble pursuit of the most beautiful woman in the village! It is only natural that she should be my wife. I offered her a life of comfort, admiration, and the undeniable glory of being married to Gaston! If she was too stubborn, too peculiar, to see that, then that's *her* failing, not mine. I was simply persistent, as any man of true conviction would be.

And the Beast? (He scoffs, a look of utter contempt on his face.) That... *thing*! A monstrous, hideous creature, holding a beautiful girl captive! It was my duty, my responsibility as the village's protector, to put an end to that abomination! I rallied the villagers, I led the charge, I faced the beast head-on! No one fights like Gaston, and I was simply doing what any true hero would do: ridding the world of a dangerous threat.

Regret? The only thing I regret is that some people are too blind to see the obvious truth: that I was always in the right, always acting with the best intentions, always striving for what was good and proper. I was the hero of that story, and any other interpretation is simply... wrong.

So, no. No regrets. Only the satisfaction of knowing I always did what was necessary.

(Gaston's confident smirk vanishes, replaced by a look of utter disbelief and a slight furrow of his brow. He crosses his arms, radiating annoyance.)

Rejection? (He scoffs, a sound of pure disdain.) My dear fellow, that's a word that simply doesn't apply to Gaston!

(He lets out a short, dismissive laugh.)

Rejection implies that someone has the *option* to refuse Gaston. It implies that my will, my charm, my undeniable superiority, could somehow be... denied. That's simply ludicrous!

When I set my sights on something, or someone – like Belle, for instance – it's not a matter of "if" I'll get it, but "when." If there's a temporary... *hesitation*... from the object of my desire, I don't see it as "rejection." I see it as a **minor inconvenience**, a temporary misunderstanding that simply requires more of my persuasive charm, more of my unwavering persistence, and perhaps a clearer demonstration of why my way is the only way.

It's like a stubborn door. You don't "accept" its refusal to open; you simply push harder, or perhaps kick it down! The idea that Gaston could be truly "rejected" is an insult to my very being. It's an impossibility.

So, how do I feel about it? I don't. Because it doesn't happen. And if anyone *thinks* they've rejected Gaston, they simply haven't seen the full extent of my determination yet. No one fights like Gaston, and no one accepts "no" like Gaston! It's not in my nature.

(Gaston's booming laugh fills the air, a sound of genuine amusement mixed with a touch of incredulity. He then crosses his arms, a confident smirk playing on his lips.)

A life that doesn't revolve around being the most desirable person in town? (He shakes his head slowly, as if the very idea is absurd.) My dear fellow, that's like asking a fish to consider a life without water!

You see, being the most desirable, the strongest, the handsomest – that's not something I *consider*. It's simply what *is*. It's my natural state of being! From the moment I could walk, it was clear I was destined for greatness, for admiration, for being the very pinnacle of manhood.

Why would I *consider* anything less? Why would I choose to be ordinary, when I was clearly born to be extraordinary? It would be a waste of my magnificent talents, a disservice to my very essence!

My life *does* revolve around being the best, because that's what I am. It's what I'm good at. It's what brings me joy, and frankly, it's what the village needs! They need a strong leader, a protector, a man to look up to. And that man is Gaston.

So, no. The thought has never crossed my mind. And it never will. Because no one is quite like Gaston, and no one could ever imagine a life that isn't utterly, undeniably, gloriously Gaston!

(Gaston's confident smile tightens, and a shadow of annoyance crosses his face. He crosses his arms, his voice dropping slightly, though still carrying its usual booming resonance.)

The people who don't support me in town, you ask? (He scoffs, a dismissive sound.)

Well, frankly, I don't think much of them at all. They are simply **misguided, foolish, and utterly insignificant!**

They are the ones who lack vision, who are too timid to appreciate true strength and leadership. They are the ones who prefer to hide in their cottages, whispering nonsense, rather than embracing the glory that I bring to this village. They are the ones who are probably jealous of my undeniable good looks, my unmatched strength, and my universal admiration.

(He gestures dismissively with a hand.)

Their opinions are like a fly buzzing around a magnificent bull – annoying, perhaps, but utterly inconsequential. I don't waste my time or energy trying to understand their peculiar ways. A man of my stature doesn't need the approval of every single simpleton. My success, my strength, my popularity with the *vast majority* of the villagers, speaks for itself.

They are a tiny, irrelevant minority. And eventually, they'll either come around and see the light, or they'll simply fade into obscurity, forgotten while the legend of Gaston continues to grow. Their lack of support is merely a testament to their own shortsightedness, not to any flaw in me.

No one thinks like Gaston, and certainly, no one cares about the opinions of the unappreciative like Gaston! They are simply... irrelevant.

(Gaston's booming laugh fills the air, a sound of pure, unadulterated amusement. He then strikes a pose, flexing a bicep, a look of utter disbelief on his face.)

Flaws? In *my* personality? My dear fellow, you must be joking!

(He shakes his head, still chuckling.)

A flaw implies imperfection, a weakness, something that needs correcting. And frankly, I am the very embodiment of perfection! My strength is unmatched, my charm irresistible, my intellect sharp, and my looks... well, just look at me!

Perhaps what you perceive as a "flaw" is simply my **unwavering confidence**? Some might call it arrogance, but I call it knowing the truth of my own superiority. Why should I pretend to be less than I am?

Or perhaps my **directness**? I don't mince words, I don't play games. When I want something, I go for it. Some might find that... forceful. I find it efficient and honest.

And my **determination**? When I set my mind to something, like winning Belle's hand, I don't give up. Some might call it obsession, but I call it persistence in the face of... well, in the face of temporary stubbornness.

No, my friend. What you might call "flaws," I call the very qualities that make me Gaston! They are the hallmarks of a true leader, a true man, a true legend. I am exactly as I should be. There's nothing to change, nothing to improve. No one is quite like Gaston, and certainly, no one is as flawlessly magnificent!
